Metadata: Measurements of nutrient metal fluxes from the sea floor in the area around the White's Point sewage outfall, Los Angeles, California
"Coastal Zone '91, Proceedings of the 7th Symposium on Coastal & Ocean Management," pp. 101-111, Long Beach, California, 1991.

Studies are underway to determine the influence of sewage outfall-​impacted sediment on the exchange of nutrients and trace metals in the California coastal marine environment. Utilizing a benthic flux chamber, researchers are collecting samples incubated in-situ for direct measurement of exchange rates. Preliminary nutrient flux measurements show that exchange rates are high enough to detect a 7-liter chamber over a 24-hour incubation period; trace metals (Fe, Mn, Co, Cu) will also be measured. Using a model, these fluxes evaluate the importance of sewage-​influenced sediments on chemical budgets in coastal waters.
